My oxygen saturation level was at 100% and my pulmonary function test showed my FEV1 was now 66% predicted. Although this was lower than I had imagined, I was still early in my recovery and as I regained my strength I was reassured by my doctors that it would go up with time.

After being discharged, I was required to stay near the hospital for regular evaluations and check-ups. Our housing, known as our “transplant house,” was at my sister’s home which was conveniently located near the transplant center. As part of my recovery outside of the hospital, my wife and I spent a lot of time walking around this new city we were in and I was able to regain my strength by being tourists and exploring parks and local attractions.

After five weeks at my transplant house, we were able to return home. The normal time to be sent home is usually about three months. I felt accomplished with my timeline of seven and a half weeks after transplant surgery. I can confidently say that none of this would have been possible without my wonderful wife who was my support, caregiver, motivator, and rock throughout this journey. To celebrate the new life my lungs provided, we decided to have our wedding rings re-blessed at the church where we were married 36 years prior.

fields.title: Post-Transplant
fields.content:
When I returned home, the first thing I wanted to do was get rid of the supplemental oxygen and medical supplies I would no longer need. I had so much more time – I saved a huge amount of time and energy from not having to do my nebulizations multiple times a day. I no longer had a productive cough.  I no longer needed to clear my throat regularly. Not everything is better, though, as there are new challenges with many new medications and immune suppression.  My biggest challenge was managing my new “medication induced diabetes”. I had to learn a lot about insulin, blood glucose, finger pricks, carbohydrates and sugar.  Luckily, a key lesson for me was that watching my diet and doing regular exercise (particularly after a meal) helped a ton! My Dexcom G6 provided great feedback and was a great incentive.

I now breathe freely and am able to do things I haven’t been able to enjoy in years.  I’m now able to look forward to years with my wife, family, and especially my grandchildren. We’ve taken trips and hiked at 10,000 feet. I am back on my snow skis and enjoyed time on the mountain.  I’m waterskiing, kayaking, swimming, and doing all my favorite water sports. I exercise, walk, or bike daily.  I’m full of energy and taking care of home projects that have long been delayed. My wife complains that watching me makes her tired. It’s just amazing.

Once you are post-transplant, things change dramatically and you go through this shift. I have been lucky to have had very few complications and a very smooth recovery. Everybody’s journey is different, and not everyone is like that. Having gone through transplant, I now enjoy coaching people as they consider and prepare for transplant by encouraging them to get as strong as possible before transplant so they have the best chance at having a good outcome. I’m also a huge advocate for caregivers and the importance they provide in addition to having a strong support system.

fields.title: My Take on Transplant
fields.content:
My suggestions for those considering a transplant are:

  • Make a decision about transplant BEFORE you’re too sick, as the evaluation process is challenging….ok, brutal.
  • Getting in shape when you’re sick is hard, but stay motivated and do as much as you can. The better physical shape you’re in, the faster your recovery. Stand-up/Sit-downs (core) and walking were my key.
  • Have a strong support system. My wife was critical to my mental, emotional, and physical success. She was my cheerleader and motivator.
  • While listed, stay positive.  Live day to day. Keep living.  The right lungs will come at the right time.
  • Expect complications or setbacks.  Everyone has them.  A good attitude will help you power through these difficult times.

Lung transplant is totally worth all the pain and effort for a second chance at life.

fields.title: Pre-Transplant & Evaluation
fields.content:
Since I was 14 years old, I was always in and out of the hospital, dealing with anywhere from three to nine exacerbations per year. Transplant was always an idea that I kept in the back of my mind. By the time I hit around 23 my FEV1, lung function, started tanking more and more. When I was 23-25 years old I already had an FEV1 of 30%.  There was one specific year when things started getting pretty drastic. I remember when it happened, it was December. I had just gone to what I thought was going to be a typical doctor’s appointment. I think the exact words I was given were something along the lines of, “It’s very likely if you don’t get this lung transplant, you’re not going to see past your 31st birthday.” At the time, I was 30.

I was told, “you have a choice here if you want to do this or not.” But if I'm honest, I didn’t really have a lot of time to interpret or think about whether I should or I shouldn’t. It felt like a necessity. I really thought there’s an urgency to this. Am I even going to make it? Am I going to actually get the lungs before I die? The decision to be referred felt so fast that I didn’t even really have much time to process it.

Never in my life have I been so anxious. I was very nervous as to what life would be like after transplant if the lung transplant is a success. What if it’s not? What happens? I thought about if I don’t have CF after transplant, what is my life going to be like? Am I going to be healthy and that’s it? Do I have what I need in my life to live a normal, suitable life after… when I'm “healthy”? There were so many topics to think about. It’s a lot. You try to maneuver around it as best as you can.

I had to prepare, and quickly. But it took a year, a year and a half, to figure everything all out and for me to be listed. I had to wait six months before I could even talk to the transplant team because I had to establish care with the local CF clinic due to a complicated adherence issue. It was excruciating, frustrating, and I had extreme anxiety. After the six months of waiting, I did the work up and in one year's worth of time I got the transplant. And during the time I was waiting, I tried to prepare mentally. I was lucky to have a therapist who knows CF.

I had a really good CF doctor - I connected with him and really appreciated that. Another person that really influenced me was my nutritionist. I knew my eating habits were pretty poor. My BMI was low. I realized I needed to be in direct contact with my nutritionist to ask her what to do about my diet. That information absolutely helped.

I did lot of research and figured out what transplant was all about. I was fortunate to have a friend who is a nurse as a resource, who helped me understand what to expect. You can read exactly how transplant works. So my logical side was taken care of. That knowledge strengthened my whole emotional and psychological well-being, and put me more at ease. Understanding for instance, what is a clamshell, the incision that they do. I wondered why don’t they cut down instead of right across? Things like that. I tried to just figure out what I could as best as I could, because I came from the mentality that this is obviously a huge deal, and it would be best to have myself educated as best I can. I felt decent about it. If I had questions, I would figure out the answers. I’m self-sufficient in that way.

fields.title: The Call, The Transplant, & The Recovery
fields.content: You still want to have enough health to recuperate from the transplant surgery. I had hemoptysis in April where I coughed up massive amounts of blood and it was understood I was essentially on my deathbed. My transplant team wrote to the UNOS lung transplant board to ask for extra points in the lung allocation score because of the serious nature of the episode. Writing the details about this occurrence would be a whole different story in itself. The odds of surviving were truly unknown. Fortunately, after 2 weeks in the ICU, I got better, and then I got my transplant in May. So, within two weeks of getting out of the ICU, I got my transplant.

fields.title: Post-Transplant
fields.content:
Right after transplant it felt like a lot. Here I was with new lungs. It was quite a transformation. Obviously my number one concern was rehabilitation. I needed to build my own schedule. Working out and doing things myself that I couldn’t do before. Your care team is there, I believe, to give you the resources, but you’ve got to do all the heavy lifting yourself. Looking back, I can see that prednisone really affected my energy and mindset, as well as focus.

After you get the transplant, your health and your quality of life substantially rises. You have to change. If your transplant is successful, you aren’t going to be living the way you were before. I needed a clear direction, and needed to figure out how to best succeed. There are steps you can take to know you are doing your best. Life was colored by the experience of having a completely new quality of life and health. It is like the lowest of the low to the highest of the high. I had so much more happiness. I was glowing and could see love everywhere. It was the honeymoon period of getting a new life.

There were some challenges with it though. I went through being sick my whole life and it was hard to break the mold. I had anxiety about what to do in life. I suppose there is a part of me that still sees myself as that sick person. The biggest challenge has been to work through that and tell myself that’s not me anymore.

Right out of transplant I started working out, hanging out with friends. I felt freedom. I was able to breathe and do more activity. What was extremely powerful was the rebirth of sorts from being critical and end-stage. I had a lot of gratitude and carry that into my interactions in life.

fields.title: My Take on Transplant
fields.content:
With end stage cystic fibrosis, your body and physical health is at it’s all time lowest. It’s exhausting, demanding, with little hope and massive isolation. To me, that was the hardest part. The ache of isolation and seeing how no one in your life is going through what you’re going through. There are people worse off than you, and simultaneously you may surround yourself with people with extremely great health. But damn near no one is going through what you’re going through.

What I’ve learned is that our physical health will bleed into our mental and emotional health. At end stage, you’ll need to keep this in mind. This is going to be the most challenging time in your life. Not just your life, but those who love you as well. My advice is to find something to fight for. If you can stomach being around people, try as best as you can to do so. You are at the end of your current life, with hope that you may have another chance. Learn how to fight every day to achieve that second chance.

There gets to be a point while waiting where you’re just too tired to want to fight. But at some point, I was like, I want to continue to live. You’ve got to believe in your own future. I had a couple of friends and some family members that would tell me I had great value to them. They were supportive, and there for me. You being around is important, so you need to fight. That’s what I tried to remember.

When I heard “you’re going to need a transplant, you're going to need to be evaluated,” I knew I had a purpose. I had to develop that purpose. I’m like “okay, this is all I'm going to do. I’m going to be focused on how I can enjoy my life as best I can with the limited health that I have, and prepare for the transplant.” My mission: to enjoy life, to fight, and to inspire.

fields.title: Pre-Transplant & Evaluation
fields.content:
I was having more and more exacerbations, and my lung function was getting close to the 30s. When it dropped that low, my doctor said, ‘I think we’re going to have to start thinking about lung transplant fairly soon.’ When he said, “fairly soon” I didn’t really know what that meant. A month? A year. I finally asked him to clarify. 

I continued to get sick that year, and after a couple of more exacerbations my doctor said that maybe I should go to the nearest transplant center (in another state) and meet the team. His reasoning was that he wanted me to be evaluated while I was still fairly healthy, that way I could stay ahead of the process rather than be put in the situation of needing an emergent transplant and having the potential to be denied for being too sick.

He was very proactive. He said that he’d like me to go to find out what it would take for me to be listed. We knew I was going to keep getting sick, and he said that if I got in the system I would be ready to go when I needed the transplant. 

My doctor knew a lot of the tests the transplant center would need to do and ordered many for me to do preemptively before I traveled down there. He did tests he was able to get insurance to cover. That made the two weeks of testing and evaluation at the transplant center a little easier and less grueling. 

Going into the first meeting with the transplant team I was under the impression that I was borderline eligible for transplant. I didn’t have in my head that I was actually going to be listed. I knew that I was getting sicker though, as I had been pretty sick that whole year, and I was on oxygen at night; and my oxygen needs were getting to be more. At the same time, I didn’t feel that sick. I thought I was just being proactive and getting established with a team so that when I did fall below that threshold of “sick enough to be listed” I would have everything ready. 

However, once I got to the transplant center and met the doctors they wasted no time. Four months after being evaluated they were ready to list me and I moved to a new state to be near the transplant center. At that point I didn’t feel that sick, I was actually feeling pretty good. A couple of months before, I had asked, “do I even need to come here, or can we wait?” They said no to waiting, because I needed a lung and liver transplant which had a longer waitlist time than lungs alone. They told me I should be listed as soon as possible while I was healthier so I could be strong enough for the surgery.

It was helpful to hear from my online transplant support group about the things that were most difficult for people, things that I could mentally prepare for. I was also reassured by the amount of success that transplant seems to have. To learn that people with CF can expect 10 years, or even more, after transplant. That the percentage of people experiencing really bad symptoms, or rejection, within the first few years is not as significant as I would have expected. I knew how long you spend in the hospital after transplant varies for everyone and the liver transplant makes it more involved. Thankfully, I made a friend who had double lung and liver transplant recently. It was helpful that my mom and I actually got to meet his mom, and my mom got to go and see him. So that was really good, and supportive for my mom. 

The transplant training was good information but we all left going, ‘what more do we need to know how to do? When we get the call, where do we go? To which door? Where do we park?’ I feel like the caretakers are kind of at a disadvantage because they need to try to figure out when to give help or not. They’re dealing with an adult who has been taking care of themselves their whole life who finds it hard to let people help. I didn’t have a sense of really how to talk to my caregivers about job descriptions for them, even after the transplant training.

One of the things I knew as I mentally prepared for this transition was that if I was going to come here and be on a waitlist for an unknown period of time, my sole job could not be waiting. I thought then about what I could be able to do with the time, as if it was a sabbatical. I know that that is definitely not the case for everybody that’s waiting for a transplant, that it’s such a mixed bag. I’ve been very, very fortunate. I’m grateful I was still able to be pretty independent. I think it would have been infinitely harder if I'd been dependent  on oxygen during the day, or getting around, or I'd needed more home care. I did need more help with daily activities when I got an exacerbation. So again, I’m very grateful that I was listed sooner, but also the reality is that being listed sooner meant I had to wait longer.

fields.title: Trikafta's Role
fields.content:
I wanted to have an open mind to what was coming down the pipeline with modulators. But I resisted trying Symdeko for a long time because I’d had such a bad experience with Orkambi. Plus, I had it in my head that I didn’t want to improve too much to kick me off the wait list, when I’d worked so hard and already waited so long for my transplant. But I was also getting exacerbations much more frequently and my quality of life was suffering. So, I decided to try Symdeko and it seemed to help keep me a little more stable. 

It was such a head game being on the transplant list: On one hand I would worry/wonder: “maybe I don’t need a transplant if this medication works…?” and on the other, I didn’t want to improve too much because I didn’t want to wait longer to get transplanted. Once Trikafta was put on the market, my doctors pretty quickly wanted to make sure I had access to it. I’d read about other people being on it who had received early access to it, so I felt comfortable starting it. My doctor made it clear that it would be unlikely that I would become healthy enough to be taken off the list, because I need both lung and liver transplants. But that it would help me improve my symptoms, which it did. Not drastically--it can’t reverse existing damage. For example, it can’t heal scarring. It can help you clear out mucus that maybe you had trouble clearing before, which is great. If I had started off being able to take it when my lungs were a little bit healthier, I think I could have gotten more of an effect. But it was really helpful in helping me stay as stable as I could.


The biggest boon was how it made coughing and doing breathing treatments a lot easier. I used to have good days and bad days with coughing, and major coughing spells came and went. But it had been years since I got a sustained reprieve from excessive coughing. Maybe a week here or there, but it would sneak up on me always. Suddenly I coughed a ton less—probably 80% less. That’s huge.  My body didn't produce the same amount of mucus that it did before. When I would wake up in the morning, my body was so different: I didn't immediately have to do breathing treatments before I could even function. I had more energy too, I wasn't as exhausted after doing breathing treatments. I could also go out in public with a lot less anxiety about having a coughing fit or getting out of breath. Now with COVID-19, that feels even more important. Everybody looks at you like you’re literally passing death around if you’re coughing. There were times before Trikafta where I would be on the bus or something, and because I’d gotten out of breath getting to the bus, when I got on the bus and my body relaxed I would usually start coughing a ton. So often I would just cough practically the whole ride. It was never comfortable to be out, and I didn’t realize how much I just wasn’t going out, or staying at home. I would go out for a walk, but I wasn’t necessarily going to go hang out in a coffee shop, because I figured it’s just not going to be comfortable for me. After I went on Trikafta, it definitely was immediately a relief. I could actually do things in a way that felt more comfortable.


It was mentally hard—I didn’t like thinking I could get healthy enough to get off the transplant list and then have to go through the evaluation all over again. I wanted to stay on the transplant list and get a transplant and get that over with, so I could move on to the next stage of my life post-transplant, rather than to have to go back to the beginning. Because I’d already started this, and gotten my head around it and done all that work for it, I wasn't going to give that up. I wanted to knuckle down and get it done. Even if Trikafta had improved my lungs enough to be delisted, I still would have been in a kind of limbo with semi-good lungs. You’re not healed. You’re just at various levels of fragility.


When you’re on the transplant list, you’re not just in a queue, with whoever is next getting the next available organs. You have a score that is determined by a lot of different numbers, which is good as it allows people that are really sick to get transplanted first, no matter how long they’ve been on the transplant list. The doctors told me they would know when the lungs were right for me--because of size and height--but that didn't tell me much about when I could get called.


It was a mental and emotional roller coaster, almost more than a physical one. I was kind of in limbo. The fear of not knowing how sick I had to be in order to trigger my turn being up. I didn’t know if I should want to get sicker so I could get transplanted sooner. My quality of life was pretty good. I didn’t need oxygen, and I was able to stay involved with my art and writing, as well as few online groups I hosted and attended. But all it would take was an exacerbation and I’d be done in and in bed for a week or two.


I was at a low point right before I started taking Trikafta. I was totally exhausted and so it was a huge relief and gave me a much-needed boost. It’s a fantastic resource that can prolong living with your body the way that you were born with it. But I’ve realized there is no right or wrong way in choosing what treatments or options are right for you. I think we have to use the medical tools that we have available to us. Transplant is something that we have available. But I would hesitate to say transplant should be looked at as “a last resort.” If your body needs a transplant, it should be fine to get a transplant. And if your body responds really positively to Trikafta, great. But also, there are some people that can’t take modulators, or that have horrible side effects when on them. I think it’s important to celebrate the possibilities, that people can prolong their lives and have a better quality of life. But at the same time, to make sure that people understand that getting a transplant isn’t a failure of something. It’s an opportunity also. If your body needs that then your body needs it, and let it be what it is.


Something important for doctors, healthcare workers, and other people to be aware of is the cost of drugs like Orkambi and Trikafta. Something I’ve talked about with people is the anxiety I had about not being able to take it anymore, or not taking it correctly. The weirdness of taking a drug that costs as much as a house down payment every month is a strange feeling that can cause a lot of anxiety and worry - what if insurance denies you at some point, what if you can’t afford to take it... It’s such an expensive lifeline, that you literally take every day, and your insurance has to approve every month. We need advocacy, so we can have access to it. It concerns me that it would be an elite drug, when it has such significant quality of life results for people. Some people may be already doing pretty good, and can start living in a way that they couldn’t before. A daily existence they didn’t think was possible. But unintended side effects for something you are so dependent on is also to be respected.


I think we have to understand the mental and emotional burden, and patterns that we get stuck in. I think sometimes we can get so stuck in our heads, especially when it’s about listening to our bodies. We think we know our bodies, and then Trikafta, this is an important part to add– every single person that I’ve communicated with said to me, I don’t know my body anymore. It doesn’t act the way that I’m used to. I’m having to relearn it all over again. That is a significant thing, because we don’t often acknowledge just how intricately we have come to know our bodies, and come to know the signs. The CF doctors are always really good about telling me, “You know your body best.” But at the same time, if we know our body best and then suddenly we don’t know our bodies, that’s a significant anxiety point. Because then it could be our fault if we get worse, or we didn’t pay attention to a sign that we didn’t know to pay attention to. The great thing about Trikafta was that I didn’t have all the symptoms anymore, but it was also disorienting and frustrating that I didn’t know the warning signs of an exacerbation like I had previously.


This sounds kind of extreme, but I think I do mean it: is it better for your mental health to not take Trikafta? Is it better to get a transplant? I think it’s important to know that there isn’t a clear right answer for the next step a lot of times. I think within all of it, it’s really important to make sure that you have a very clear sense of what your values are. And what quality of life is for you. It is a mental game. It really does take compassionate listening with somebody else when you get stuck in your head. We can make these decisions on our own, but at the same time, I really need my husband to be like, no, this is what I’m seeing. And I need my doctor to be like, this is what I’m seeing. I need to be able to trust them to be looking at me from a compassionate, helpfully, critical thinking lens. There’s natural suffering, and then there’s unnecessary suffering, and the work is to discern between the two so you can address what needs addressing, and let the rest of it be.

fields.title: Pre-Transplant & Evaluation
fields.content:
We were told originally that we may not have our two sons with CF much longer than age 12. But things changed very quickly. We made sure that we were very proactive. We did all the therapies, from the time they were little. The clapping – all of the things. We would always talk with the boys about never using CF as an excuse not to do something. You’re going to get out there, and if you want to do sports, we’re going to do it. And you’re going to go to school. Early on, I would plant myself in the library and read the newest articles, look at anatomy books, and try to understand functions affected by the disease. I would read about the treatments. That was what I needed to do.

When it came to the transplant, the whole idea all of those years was, we’re going to do everything we can. I felt that my sons would probably never need a transplant. Our whole thing around transplant, from the time they were diagnosed, was it’s a last resort. When we did learn a little bit about it, very early on when the boys were young, it almost seemed like a stopgap measure. It’s going to buy a little bit of time, and then oh my gosh, do the lungs re-infect? Are we in for two or three transplants? What is this all about? It was so big and seemed so distant, that we hoped we would never have to do it.

When it came down to my son Jacob needing one, it was very scary. Not knowing what lay ahead in the future. You start spiraling out a little bit. When we got to that point, it was hurry up and learn. We knew of a couple of people that went through it, many people that had not made it through, or rejected years later. We didn’t even know what was the best information or statistics. It was quick. We went in for all the meetings and there was so much information coming at us very quickly. They threw out numbers and averages. I didn’t hear everything, it was hard to listen objectively.

Jake was told, you probably should start thinking about this. His doctor told him “you’re not quite ready for it yet, but you’re definitely heading in that direction.” He had made the decision, after looking on the internet and different things, that “I’m not going to do this. I’m not going to take my family through something I’m not going to survive. It sounds horrible.” Then as he got sicker, one of the home infusion nurses put him in touch with somebody who had had the surgery, who was about his age and other kinds of things. A lot of parallels. We went to meet with them, and then said, “okay I think I can do this”, and he made the decision to have the transplant.

fields.title: The Call, The Transplant, & The Recovery
fields.content:
By the time he made the decision he was spiraling down so quickly. He had dragged his feet, got the flu, and things had really gone downhill. He was literally in his 11th hour. We were in the hospital, and he was on ten liters of oxygen, and they said there’s really nothing more we can do here. We’re going to send you home tomorrow. And that is the first time, and the only time, he ever said to me, I am not worth this. There’s nothing I can do, I’m not going to survive this. I just was, stop. We’re going to continue to fight this. There’s more, I know there’s more. And that’s when we got the call, that night at about 11:30, midnight, that he was going to get the lungs. The expectation, I think, from some of the docs was that he wasn’t going to make it through. But he worked very, very hard, and he had such a big heart for it, and such a good attitude. I’m going to do this. And he did, he worked really hard.  

He had his same port when he went in to get his transplant. When he went into pre-op, the nurse was not familiar with his port, and tried to access it a couple of times. He said, just call my mom in here. I gowned up and accessed the port. For me, it was easy because I had been doing it for years. It was just not something that they were familiar with. The same thing happened on the floor. And I said, you can watch me, or I’ll walk you through it. Either way, I can do it.  It had to be done.

There are foundations out there – there’s support. Not just to pay for a transplant. Jake happened to fall under Obamacare at the time that first came out. We were prepared to put up our house, and every belonging that we had, because his insurance had a cap. He was working. We were going to fill that gap but we were $300,000 short. Okay here’s our house title. We pushed that through the little pay window, and they said, we can’t do that. But very soon after that, the cap was lifted, Obamacare came into effect and his whole surgery was covered. Meanwhile our family, friends and EMS in our county started fundraising.

But then there’s all the ancillary stuff. The hotel or the apartment to stay in that you have to be close to the hospital. The food, the gas, all of that. There are places that cover that, that can help with that. And you don’t have to feel, well I’m on assistance. Or Medicaid, thinking I probably don’t qualify for that. You do. There’re people that really want to help. Jake decided to start a foundation for people that were in his position with the money that was being raised by the fundraising being done by family, friends and EMS family. It exists today and has benefited two other CF patients working on lung transplant and his brother Derek.

As a caregiver, you need someone to talk to. You should also talk to someone who has been through it. I’ve had people tell me, you’ve been through it twice. When we went through it later with his younger brother, we heard, “oh you’ve already been through it, this is going to be a breeze.” No, it’s not going to be a breeze. I still have my son on an operating table. To me, it was still dire type circumstances. A big deal. People had no point of reference, it wasn’t that they were being uncaring or anything. They were trying to be supportive, but they had no frame of reference. Every experience is different. Even if you’ve been through it two times or more. There are probably families that have been through more than we have been through. It’s okay to be angry, it’s okay to be sad, it’s okay to be happy. And it’s okay when you feel guilty, someone can tell you, let’s talk through it. Don’t just put a label on it and say, well you shouldn’t or you should. That kind of support. If we could get good at putting more of that together, I think that would be great. For the families.

After his transplant, Jake stayed in the hospital for a while. Later, when his brother Derek had a transplant, he just breezed through. It was a total night and day experience with the two of them. Jake had a little bit more of a challenge. While Jake was in the hospital, we said okay, we’re going to walk a little bit further every day. Even if it’s a step. We started there, and before he went home, he was walking up and down the stairs inside the hospital. He had a lot of inspiration, he had a banner in his room signed by a whole conference of EMS (Emergency Medical Services) people. They were a big part of our support system. We have an absolutely huge support system. I didn’t even realize how big it was. My family, the boys, have had a tremendous outpouring of caring. When the boys were little, they thought some of the people that came to the house were relatives. We’re very very fortunate in our situation. 

When he got out of the hospital, we made sure that there was a place for him and his wife, and there was an extra bedroom so that we could come up and help. His wife had to learn all of that stuff too, to help out with it. He had dressings that needed to be changed. We used to call it silly string. The bandage that looked like continuous string, to pack in where his wound was. The first night, he was going to try and do it himself when he got home. It just kept coming and coming, and he kept getting greener and greener. I got a phone call saying, Mom you know what? I hate to ask you this, but can you come and help me change this?

Anything that he needed afterwards, or they needed, he and his wife, we were there and so were Mary’s (his wife’s) parents. Jake and Mary bought a house, ultimately, which was probably less than ten minutes from where we live. He knew what to do too, he was a go-getter. His wife had to learn how to do a lot too, how to take care of him. She is a trooper. The payoff was that they could do things again. They could go play tennis, they could go on a car trip, they could do things.

Even though I knew there was a possibility of rejection or other issues, he looked so good after his transplant. Getting pink, gaining weight. His fingers weren’t clubbed anymore. He was enjoying life. It was a time I could say, I’m not afraid to be happy. I was hoping he would outlive me. It was easy to think he and his brother would be left after we went. We did our will and each were assigned this and that. That was the expectation, that they could go on forever.

fields.title: Post-Transplant
fields.content:
Jake and his wife moved to Alaska, and we went to visit often and saw our granddaughter. Then one day he called me and said, Mom I’m having trouble just taking a deep breath. I said, can you describe it? He said it feels like I can take a breath just fine, but it’s like my lungs aren’t inflating all the way. That was his complaint. I said, you need to go in. They treated him for an infection in Alaska, but things just started to go down. Then they realized he was rejecting. It was acute.

He was airlifted down here to Washington, and was in the hospital for a while. They tried many therapies to try to stop the rejection process. We brought him home, and we knew that this wasn’t good. I guess I was in fight mode, and denial mode. His wife asked me, what happens if he doesn’t make it through this? And I said, I am not allowing myself to think that. We’re going to keep doing everything we need to do. We tried every therapy, everything we could to do get him at least back up to where he could qualify for possibly another transplant. We got a belly tube put in, so we were feeding him 24 hours. He took all of his medications.

Things went very, very fast. Just months. He was really struggling. He knew. I stayed home from work; his brother stayed with him a lot. The day he passed away he got up and I told him I could help him get up from bed. But after he went back to bed he didn’t wake up. I panicked. It was fast, and very difficult.

It doesn’t get any easier, but you learn to cope a little bit. His brother seemed lost for a while. They had fun together throughout their lives. I feel for him when I think about it, knowing that he too would go through lung transplant. Derek suffered, I could tell from his behavior. I know sometimes he was depressed. We talked about getting back to life.

When Derek’s health started to decline further, we moved him to a mobile home on our property that we’d fixed up. He was close by, but could have his life. The requirements had changed for lung transplant for him. Eligibility and selection were different. We were prepared in some ways, because we knew what was coming since we’d been through it before. At the transplant class we were able to learn a bit more. We knew transplant was it, that it was what we had to do and we had hopes. Again, we had the attitude that he should outlive us.

Derek got his lung transplant when he was less advanced in his disease, not like his brother. He didn’t think he was as sick as he needed to be. He said when he got the call, he was like, “are you sure?” I was in a meeting when he called me. He made a joke about going to dinner in Seattle that night. It dawned on me what he was doing, that we were getting lungs, and off we went. I think we were a little bit more prepared, obviously.

It was a surprise; how quick it went. We were prepared to wait. It just went super-fast, but this time up instead of downhill. When the lungs came, it was like, oh my gosh that was amazingly quick. It was like, he’s doing this already, you’re kidding. He wasn’t apprehensive, just a little nervous. We’d had talked about chest tubes and how he was going to have more of them. He knew they were not that painful, because there’s not that many nerve receptors there. He had chest tubes when he had a spontaneous pneumothorax.  We’d talk about stuff like that.

It just was so different. Jake had been scared of needles. He had a litany of things going on. He talked about letting go, not wanting any heroics. Two different kids completely, but both tremendous individuals. With Derek, the conversation was different. If his lungs started to fail he’d want to fight. If we ever saw signs of rejection, we wouldn’t mess around.

He’s gaining weight and doing all these things – he was playing football with some of the little kids the other day, and it’s just so fun to watch again. He can do these things again.

fields.title: My Take on Transplant
fields.content:
My boys and I have been able to talk about anything. I would encourage people to have a conversation with their loved one about their wishes. Jake was very pragmatic about these types of conversations. With Derek, we could broach the subject and nothing would be off limits. He knows about our will. These are things to talk about. I don’t think it’s a conversation to be afraid of. Having it ahead of time and knowing, is a good thing. Right now, he is doing so well. But there can be false hope that happens when they get very sick. You can’t just know. We had to go through this conversation with Jake, and there was stuff he just didn’t want. It was a hard reality for us.

I know things happen and are beyond our control. I would advise people not to worry. It’s like paying interest on something you’ll never own. You won’t enjoy life, you won’t enjoy your children. When my kids were little I worried all the time about them leaving me and what I would do. It can be horrible. What if, what if, all the time. I was being a caregiver more than a mom. You can question and learn all you can, but you can also have faith. Ultimately you have to let go. Do the things that you know you need to do and enjoy what you have. Concentrate on what you have.

At the seven-year mark I might start watching Derek like a hawk. I watch him now. I’m not naïve. I always check and see how he’s doing, but we don’t want to talk about something going wrong constantly. I just want to hear from him, but I don’t want either of us to spend our lives worrying. He’s got a whole new lease on life and he should run with it. We’re going to go 110%-- whatever years we can get out of it. I have confidence, things are good, and his team is fantastic. I know that they’re watching him, I know he’s doing everything he’s supposed to do. We look at it like a gift--it is one.

The doctors were going to try some of the new therapies with him before he got the call. We appreciate what we’ve got, although there are no guarantees. It is great if the new medications work for other people and it would be nice to know that. But honestly, I didn’t look at those because it turned out to not matter for us. If there is something we can try in the future to augment what he does now, we will learn more. If he got into trouble with rejection we would change our tactics. The CF Foundation has worked very hard, and there is a lot of research that could help people hold out without getting a transplant. We would celebrate alongside those people and be happy for their successes.

fields.title: Pre-Transplant & Evaluation
fields.content:
I was surprised to be told I could get a lung transplant, and I questioned whether I’d get to transplant and be told I’m not ready, then have to go through another evaluation to get to that point later. I didn’t realize that 35% lung function was low enough to be referred. I guess my CF doctor brought it up because of my need for so many IV antibiotics in one year. At first, they didn’t cover a lot of the specifics. They knew that I would ask enough questions if I needed to. But I liked how they just looked at me and said “so how do you feel about transplant? I was thinking about referring you, how would you feel about that?” Obviously, that seemed like the right approach.

When I had my first appointment with the transplant team I had to cancel because I couldn’t bear the thought of going through tests at the hospital after what had happened during my last stay. I talked to a psychologist, and three or four months later started again. It took a fair amount of courage to finally do it, considering how long I’ll be in-patient after surgery. But the transplant team was very helpful. They were so good with my family members and answered their questions in an organized way and it wasn’t too long of a day for us. My partner didn’t have any idea what he was supposed to do or not do after a transplant.

In the past when I thought of transplant, I was apprehensive. I thought about what my family members would go through, more than me. I think the worst risk is to put my family through all of this, have them take all the time off and get into the mindset that I’ve going to live, and then possibly I don’t even live through the surgery, or I get rejection and then they are stuck in the caregiver role. The point of transplant, I believe, is to get not only yourself, but those around you, a little more freedom. I’m worried that it’ll just end up shackling them more to me.

I also wondered if I wanted to be kept alive that long with so many things wrong in my body, as if I was an experiment. I feel in the first generation to live this long. No one told me as a kid that I was going to live as long as I was. I thought I would die mid-20s. What if things are going too far? I wasn’t sure if all the doctors that see me were on the same page. What about how my kidneys would do? Honestly, my lungs and my heart seem better than the rest of me. Which isn’t saying much.

I’ve known of people through Facebook who I’ve talked to about lung transplant. It seems like a highly variable, person by person process of what’s going to go wrong, and no one really has any idea until it happens. Which is the most frightening thing about it, because I have a little OCD about being ahead of the curve, so I can avoid things before they happen. And to have to put my trust in people that I haven’t really met yet is scary. But I’m amazed that some people last 15 years, or have less years but they say the years are great.

I honestly haven’t talked too much with my doctors about treatment decisions. I know when to ask for IV antibiotics, and we talk about if I need my pills upgraded to a stronger dose. I always have concerns about IV antibiotics because they’ve given me kidney problems and I’m at the point of needing a kidney transplant.

I just had my fourth sinus surgery. We also had to focus on controlling my diabetes. Mine is really hard to control, and I was trying to work with my diabetes doctors to get a pump and a Dexcom continuous glucose monitor (CGM), but being on Medicaid, they said there was no way to get either. I waited for ten years, and until I finally got fed up and I just called the makers of pumps and CGMs, and three months later I had both. It was kind of heartbreaking. I’m also using an app called Android APS (Artificial Pancreas System), and it got my A1C down from 9 to 5.7. When you’re a Medicaid patient you have to fight to be given the best medications.

I had a hospitalization earlier this year for ten days and things went horribly wrong. It’s scary as hell to be admitted to the hospital, especially if you don’t have someone with you like a family member at all times. It’s hard to ask your family members to live in the hospital. I think it really depends on the luck of the draw what doctor you have, how well they know the ins and outs of Medicaid, and how well they go to bat for you. The staff can be dismissive, and there is always a new doctor. No one ever tells you the doctor’s name. It’s always a frightening experience.

fields.title: Trikafta's Role
fields.content:
My lung function went from 35% to 45% of predicted as I was going through the transplant process taking Symdeko (tezacaftor/ivacaftor). I tried not to think about how things would be after a lung transplant, because I don’t want to jinx things. I didn’t want to focus on what wasn’t guaranteed to happen. And I came to feel that I was too healthy for transplant. I certainly didn’t want to get one before I needed one when I can wait until I actually need it. I wasn’t even on oxygen.

Eight months ago, I was prescribed Trikafta (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor). The approval was quite easy, it was surprising. I had maybe one more meeting before they were going to decide to list me for a lung transplant. Within a few weeks I had gained almost 20 percent lung function. It wasn’t even my decision, they just took me off the transplant list. They couldn’t justify it. My lung function got up to 57% with only a month and a half of the medication. It was quite a shock actually. That was the main emotion. As far as I can tell the doctors aren’t really sure what to think about it and I’ve only had two appointments by video call during the time I’ve been on it. They probably aren’t sure if it is going to last and I’m not sure it was going to last, but it has for eight months. I don’t know how I’d handle getting worse, but I’m also not sure I could handle getting any better.

I have energy. I’ve painted one door five times for something to do, although in part that’s probably from boredom due to the pandemic. Each day I cough maybe five times- that’s it in comparison to every other second previously. I haven’t had one dose of IVs since going on Trikafta. I haven’t had to go to the ER even once. I didn’t have any memory of feeling this good. It’s good timing because if you cough outside right now with the pandemic, people don’t like you, which makes sense. It was amazing. I feel better now than I did 15 years ago. Pretty much everything is different. It’s overwhelmingly bizarre. I couldn’t imagine not coughing up green phlegm every day. Now when I blow my nose it’s clear. It’s not horrifying like when I was sick.

It’s been a weird adjustment to spend the better part of a decade thinking you are going to die and then need to prepare that you can live 15-20 more years. It is quite a change to wake up- mentally and physically and realize you haven’t lived your life. I don’t have much work experience, and even if I want to work I can’t because I’m on social security and I need to keep it for the medication. I’m alive, and now I look around and realize I am so stuck. What do I do with this health if I can’t work? I know I’m supposed to be really happy, but I’m not in my early twenties. I don’t have time to go to school and create a career trajectory. If I went to school I’d be looking for someone to hire me at 42.

When I was last healthy enough to work I lost a big portion of my SSI for about a year because of the percentage they took out for every dollar I earned. Then I lost my job because I got sick and couldn’t get healthy enough again to work, and it took four months to get my SSI re-instated. Luckily, I still had my insurance. Right now, I’m aware that if I worked I would only have so many months before they cut my checks and I lost my insurance. Damned if you do damned if you don’t. I do have a job interview coming up. I feel like I have to do something, I’m losing my mind. As a woman you feel like you should be contributing to the household now that you’re healthy enough to do so. I’ve been trying to live on $420 of SSI a month and I’m not doing so great at that. And I need to be able to pay my rent and my bills, but if I lose my insurance I’m in trouble. I have many many more medications than Trikafta that I have to have. I’ve had CF so long there are so many things that have gone wrong. How could I depend on insurance from a business that is small and ask them to cover Trikafta and eight other medications?

I’ve had some side effects from the Trikafta. In the beginning I lost half of my hair. But I guess my body has adjusted to whatever it was going through. My hair is growing back in every direction and is about three and a half inches long. My attention span seems about two seconds long in comparison to what it used to be. It is as if I’m in the only generation that is in this in-between phase. We’re like the last people with polio. But you do the best you can because that’s all you can do.

People on Facebook and forums are all talking about Trikafta 24/7. It seems like I’m having similar issues from what I read. It’s hard to keep a handle on your emotions, but maybe that is because those of us on it aren’t used to being fully alive and it takes a while to get back to what other people feel all of the time. Emotions are magnified enormously. I think it has to do with having a new lease on life but without a real future. We have a lot of things in our lives we didn’t get a chance to examine before because everything was an emergency.  There is a guilt factor where you don’t want to feel anger or depressed because look where you are now. You don’t want to tell your doctor that you are dissatisfied with getting to live longer. But it would be nice to have a regular job and get used to living with a schedule and have things to get up for in the morning that matter. That would make a world of difference.

I've stopped having frequent exacerbations on Trikafta, and my lung transplant referral was closed.

fields.title: The Call, The Transplant, & The Recovery
fields.content:
I was getting IV antibiotics about once a month. I was run down, low energy and motivation, and just getting through. The day I got the call I had reached out to my nurse in the morning because I'd coughed up blood the night before, which was common for me. I thought, thank god! 

 I was definitely surprised, because it had been two and a half years. I was like, oh, wow. I was pretty calm. I was surprised and relieved, I was excited, and I felt pretty peaceful. I had just been thinking about how I needed to get more organized for transplant! The call came in at 2:30 in the afternoon after I'd eaten and was just hanging out. It was a good timeline, not a horrible rush. I had time to absorb it and talk to people, which was nice. We had a few hours to get ready to go to the hospital. I started calling people and letting them know. They told me to come in at 8pm at night and that if everything was a go, my surgery would be at 10am the next morning. 

They knocked me out after a couple of minutes of getting in the OR. They said okay are you ready and I said I guess. See you on the other side. Then I woke up five days later. I don’t remember anything, the surgery or the five days that I was out. The surgery was 15 and a half hours I think? I just remember going in, then I remember waking up. I was told it went really well, no complications, just a vein they had to manuever when they were doing my liver. 

My mouth was drier than it had ever been when I woke up.  It felt like a desert. I woke up with the ventilator and the tube in my mouth. But I was really, really frustrated immediately. Get this thing out of my mouth, I need some water. I couldn’t communicate well because one, I had something in my mouth, and two, my mouth was so dry. And they kept asking, what do you want? I was so, so frustrated, beyond frustrated. My husband wasn’t understanding me, I was trying to sign letters to him. He’s like, what, huh? Nobody was getting me. Finally after 20 minutes I got across that I’m thirsty, I need water. They said you can’t have it because you’ll aspirate. I was so mad. They said, your breathing isn’t quite there yet. You’re at 10 and you need to have 20 breaths per minute or something like that. I didn’t know how to get it there. I couldn't even think I was so thirsty.

They took everything out and said, ok this is your first breath. It felt weird. The nurses were all really great, but they wanted to do a bunch of things when they came in before I could have water or ice chips. My pain the first two nights was really rough. It took awhile to get my pain meds under control, but once that was resolved I was more comfortable and things got better.

fields.title: Post-Transplant
fields.content:
Recovery was harder than I thought it would be. I needed help getting off the toilet, off the couch, low chairs and stuff. I was still on precautions, so I couldn’t use my arms. A lot of things that I wanted to do I couldn’t do, either because I didn’t have the energy or I didn’t have the ability. My days were usually pretty packed with breathing treatments, and PT, and doctors – I had four teams that would come see me each day. During my down time, I slept. That’s all I wanted. But it did get long towards the end, and I just wanted to go home.

It was nice to be home with my husband, because I couldn't have visitors for awhile in the hospital because of COVID restrictions. It was definitely a challenge to figure out the meds, and the new schedule. Make sure that I was eating enough. My husband was having to juggle a lot on his end, with the house and the cooking. I think we were both surprised at how hard it was. It was definitely challenging that first couple of weeks. It did get easier, every day was a little bit easier.

At first it was weird how my diaphragm muscles weren't there anymore from the surgery. I had gurgles and crackling in my lungs, from the surgery and all the fluid. With CF, you know you have to clear it, but I realized it was fine for things to work themselves out. There were clues, like being ok sleeping in one position on my back. I didn't feel that different, but I wasn't coughing. My lungs weren't fully expanded, until one day when it felt amazing to breathe. I started to have moments of wow, this is going to be really good. There were certain times when my lungs would start to relax. With pure breath, there was no pain or discomfort. Then there were times I was still in pain or out of breath. I was better, but still with the energy and weakness levels of pre-transplant. Working on getting in shape, strong, and building my muscles became important. 

It's nice getting PFTs now and seeing the numbers go up (85% of predicted) instead of down. I have limitations, but I can get there. Walking is important. Trying to do what you can. Having goals about doing what you want to do. I’m definitely looking forward to just being able to expand my physical abilities. Recreationally go on hikes, or biking with my husband. Over the years your world gets small.

fields.title: My Take on Transplant
fields.content:
On the one hand, I’m glad it took as long as it did. I did feel like I was ready about a year after I was on the list waiting. But I also can look back and see all these different phases. Accepting and getting my head around transplant. I definitely had a lot of anxiety starting the process. Then feeling like I needed to make all these lists, and get things together. Then I’d fizzle out!

It is important to address your anxiety and worry, find ways to address how you feel. It is legit. Take steps to worry less, to be present. By the time I got the call, I had already worked through all of this grasping for control, and I was like, it’s going to be fine. Whatever happens, no problem. I was so peaceful and the whole process really was very peaceful for me. I got excellent care. It ended up being a very positive experience for me. I think my internal state was calm and I was able to go with the flow a lot more, and just be more present, and also curious about it. And therefore, I think hopefully I was a lot more pleasant to deal with. There were low level discomforts and I needed work arounds because it was hard to be an advocate for myself. But it is important to push a bit. Don’t forget to say please and thank you, make their job as easy as possible. Do not make them guess what you need and what you want.

I’d say on the emotional, mental, and spiritual level, you have to decide how you’re going to go into the waiting. What other things can you focus on that have to do with personal growth, or using the time to prepare. This is your time to reckon with a lot of those harder questions. Who you are, and why you want to do this, and what you are living for, and what brings you joy. Especially if you have a longer waiting time, you start to realize that time is really invaluable. You could spend all of your time waiting with bated breath, but that’s exhausting. And it starts to put you into this boundary that doesn’t need to exist. Like you can’t say yes to anything, or you can’t start big projects because you’re afraid you’ll get interrupted, and then you’d be unreliable, then people would think bad of you. And it’s just not true, especially if you’re out front saying, just know I could get called at any time.

One thing that I said to myself over and over, it’s going to happen when it’s supposed to happen. I chose that I was going to believe that, and not be anxious about it not happening. It will happen when it’s supposed to happen, and that’s just the way it is.
I really began noticing a decline in my health and an impact on my ability to do things in my 50’s.
Transplant wasn't something I saw for myself.
Make a decision about transplant BEFORE you’re too sick, as the evaluation process is challenging….ok, brutal.
I now breathe freely and am able to do things I haven’t been able to enjoy in years.
At first, I just went to my doctor to hear about it, to consider it, but then my body crashed and it became a conversation where transplant was the only option I had left.
I was doing really well after transplant and I got out of the hospital earlier than expected.

Being a Black woman with cystic fibrosis and being a Black woman navigating through the healthcare system in general, I am more than used to actions toward me becoming racially charged when I try to advocate for myself. But this situation led me to feel more alone than ever because I was more vulnerable than I had ever been.
They couldn’t extubate me and decided to keep me on a ventilator, thinking my lungs could improve with treatment and therapy.
Trikafta helped me with going through the process of waiting.
I woke up and they said to me you don’t have new lungs. It was a trial run, or a dry run. We were told it can happen even multiple times, but it was disappointing.
I was diagnosed with skin cancer a couple months after the transplant conversation, and then had to wait two years after my biopsy surgery before I was eligible for transplant.

I watched the YouTube video of the woman breathing for the first time after her lung transplant surgery and the tube being taken out and dreamed about having that same moment of being able to experience breathing easy!

I had just gone to what I thought was going to be a typical doctor's appointment. I think the words I was given were something along the lines of, “It’s very likely if you don’t get this lung transplant, you’re not going to see past your 31st birthday.”
Never in my life have I been so anxious.
I had a hemoptysis occurrence in April where I coughed up massive amounts of blood and it was understood I was essentially on my deathbed.

My doctor made it clear that it would be unlikely that I would become healthy enough to be taken off the list, because I need both lung and liver. But that Trikafta would help me improve my symptoms and keep me stable, which it did and has.

But because I’d already started down the transplant road and been listed for over a year, and it took so much mental and emotional work to be okay with where I was...I had come so far I wanted to see transplant through.
I felt that my sons would probably never need a transplant. Our whole thing around transplant, from the time they were diagnosed, was it’s a last resort.
When it came down to one of my sons needing one, it was very scary. Not knowing what lay ahead in the future. You start spiraling out a little bit.
As a caregiver, you need someone to talk to. You should also talk to someone who has been through it.

I questioned whether I’d get to transplant and be told I’m not ready. I didn’t realize that 35% lung capacity was low enough to be referred. The transplant team was very helpful - they were so good with my family members and answered their questions.
Right now, I feel I’m too healthy for transplant.

My doctor wanted me to be evaluated while I was still fairly healthy, that way I could stay ahead of the process rather than be put in the situation of needing an emergent transplant and having the potential to be denied for being too sick.

fields.name: increasing frequency of exacerbations (from months to weeks)
Increasing frequency of hemoptysis (coughing up blood)
osteoporosis from chronic prednisone use (required hip replacement surgery)
chronic hypoxic/hypercapnic respiratory failure on a ventilator via a tracheostomy
On oxygen all the time (even at rest)
multiple respiratory viruses (rhinovirus infections – the “common cold”)
Exacerbation
fields.description: Pulmonary exacerbations are flares of cystic fibrosis lung disease that are typically associated with worsened symptoms (increased cough, sputum production, shortness of breath) and decrease in lung function (e.g. FEV1).
fields.content: Pulmonary exacerbations are flares of cystic fibrosis lung disease that are typically associated with worsened symptoms (increased cough, sputum production, shortness of breath) and decrease in lung function (e.g. FEV1).

fields.name: Life Expectancy
fields.description: Survival after lung transplant is tracked by multiple patient registries, including the CF Foundation, the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS), and the International Society for Heart and Lung Transplantation (ISHLT).  The ISHLT provides information on how long people from all over the world with various diseases have lived after lung transplant. For people with CF transplanted between 1990 and 2018, half lived longer than 10 years after transplant, and half lived less than 10 years.
fields.content:
Survival after lung transplant is tracked by multiple patient registries, including the CF Foundation, the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS), and the International Society for Heart and Lung Transplantation (ISHLT).

The ISHLT provides information on how long people from all over the world with various diseases have lived after lung transplant. For people with CF transplanted between 1990 and 2018, half lived longer than 10 years after transplant, and half lived less than 10 years. The term for this is the “median survival”. In fact, 1 out of 4 CF lung transplant recipients has lived more than 20 years after transplant. ISHLT data also show improving survival for lung transplant recipients with CF over time, with more recent transplants providing a longer survival benefit.

fields.name: Slow decline
fields.description: It's slow dude.
