fields.name: Advance Care Planning
fields.description: People with serious illness benefit by planning for a future where they are likely to get sicker so that they can communicate their preferences to their providers and caregivers. Advance care planning is a process that includes conversations about treatment preferences as well as wishes for end-of-life care. As part of the lung transplant evaluation process, people with CF are expected to complete an advanced directive. The CFF recommends routine advance care planning conversations once FEV1< 40
fields.content: People with serious illness benefit by planning for a future where they are likely to get sicker so that they can communicate their preferences to their providers and caregivers. Advance care planning is a process that includes conversations about treatment preferences as well as wishes for end-of-life care. As part of the lung transplant evaluation process, people with CF are expected to complete an advanced directive. The CFF recommends routine advance care planning conversations once FEV1< 40% predicted.

fields.name: Disability
fields.description: Disability, or Social Security Disability Insurance, is a program that pays benefits to individuals who have worked long enough and recently enough and paid Social Security taxes on your earnings. The Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program pays benefits to disabled adults and children who have limited income and resources.
fields.content: Disability, or Social Security Disability Insurance, is a program that pays benefits to individuals who have worked long enough and recently enough and paid Social Security taxes on your earnings. The Supplemental Security Income (SSI) program pays benefits to disabled adults and children who have limited income and resources.

fields.name: Tests
fields.description: Specific tests vary based on your age, medical history, how sick you are, the transplant program, and other factors. Some tests may be already completed as part of routine CF care and the transplant team will need to gather records. Tests may include: pulmonary function testing, blood tests, chest radiology (x-ray or CF scan), etc.
fields.content:
Specific tests vary based on your age, medical history, how sick you are, the transplant program, and other factors. Some tests may be already completed as part of routine CF care and the transplant team will need to gather records.

Tests may include: pulmonary function testing; blood tests; chest radiology (x-ray or CT scan); evaluation of your heart (echocardiogram and heart catheterization); evaluation for acid reflux and esophagus function; and cancer screening.

fields.name: Lung Transplant Evaluation
fields.description: The transplant team will outline a list of specific steps that you will need to finish before you can be placed on the waiting list. The steps will be a combination of tests, procedures, and visits with medical providers.
fields.content:
The transplant team will outline a list of specific steps that you will need to finish before you can be placed on the waiting list. The steps will be a combination of tests, procedures, and visits with medical providers.

The goals of the “evaluation” are to:

(1) Better determine how much you can benefit from transplant

(2) Identify conditions that could be optimized to improve your chance of success with transplant.

(3) Identify conditions that could make transplant too risky (contraindications)

fields.name: Survival Statistics
fields.description: Survival after lung transplant is tracked by multiple patient registries, including the CF Foundation, the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS), and the International Society for Heart and Lung Transplantation (ISHLT).   The ISHLT provides informa
fields.content:
Survival after lung transplant is tracked by multiple patient registries, including the CF Foundation, the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS), and the International Society for Heart and Lung Transplantation (ISHLT).

The ISHLT provides information on how long people from all over the world with various diseases lived after lung transplant. For people with CF transplanted between 1990 and 2018, half lived longer than 9.9 years after transplant, and half lived less than 9.9 years. The term for this is the “median survival”. In fact, 1 out of 4 CF lung transplant recipients has lived more than 20 years after transplant. ISHLT data also shows improving survival for lung transplant recipients with CF over time, with more recent transplants providing a longer survival benefit.

fields.name: BMI
fields.description: BMI (body mass index) is measure of nutrition that incorporates a person’s height and weight. A BMI that is too high (obesity) or too low (malnutrition) can make transplant riskier. In fact, there are studies showing that people with obesity or malnutrition before transplant are at a higher risk for having a difficult recovery and worse survival after transplant. For this reason, being moderately-to-severely underweight or being obese can make a person ineligible for lung transplant.
fields.content: BMI (body mass index) is measure of nutrition that incorporates a person’s height and weight. A BMI that is too high (obesity) or too low (malnutrition) can make transplant riskier. In fact, there are studies showing that people with obesity or malnutrition before transplant are at a higher risk for having a difficult recovery and worse survival after transplant. For this reason, being moderately-to-severely underweight or being obese can make a person ineligible for lung transplant. The BMI thresholds, or absolute cutoffs, are different at different transplant programs across the country.

fields.name: Feeding Tube
fields.description: Feeding tubes can be temporary or more durable. Temporary feeding tubes may be inserted into the nose and go into the stomach or small intestine. More durable feeding tubes (e.g. PEG or G-tube) can be placed by surgeons, gastroenterologists or interventional radiologists and are typically connected to the surface of the skin on the left upper portion of the abdomen. Either type of feeding tube can be used to deliver liquid tube feedings.
fields.content: Feeding tubes can be temporary or more durable. Temporary feeding tubes may be inserted into the nose and go into the stomach or small intestine. More durable feeding tubes (e.g. PEG or G-tube) can be placed by surgeons, gastroenterologists or interventional radiologists and are typically connected to the surface of the skin on the left upper portion of the abdomen. Either type of feeding tube can be used to deliver liquid tube feedings.

fields.name: Support Group
fields.description: Support groups exist for people considering lung transplant and their caregivers. Many support groups have a virtual component (or are entirely online). Support groups offer the opportunity to learn about lung transplant from others who have gone through the process and to share your experiences before and after transplant.
fields.content: Support groups exist for people considering lung transplant and their caregivers. Many support groups have a virtual component (or are entirely online). Support groups offer the opportunity to learn about lung transplant from others who have gone through the process and to share your experiences before and after transplant.

fields.name: Caregiver
fields.description: Being a caregiver is a commitment. Lung transplant caregiver requirements vary by lung transplant program, but generally must be adults who are nonsmokers, able to drive, and able to stay at the hospital while the patient is recovering from the transplant surgery. Caregivers are useful for providing physical help – carrying/transporting medical equipment, delivering needed items to the hospital, and providing meals.
fields.content: Being a caregiver is a commitment. Lung transplant caregiver requirements vary by lung transplant program, but generally must be adults who are nonsmokers, able to drive, and able to stay at the hospital while the patient is recovering from the transplant surgery. Caregivers are useful for providing physical help – carrying/transporting medical equipment, delivering needed items to the hospital, and providing meals.

fields.name: Pulmonary Rehabilitation
fields.description: Pulmonary rehabilitation is a supervised program that includes exercise training, health education, and breathing techniques for people who have certain lung conditions or lung problems.
fields.content: Pulmonary rehabilitation is a supervised program that includes exercise training, health education, and breathing techniques for people who have certain lung conditions or lung problems.

fields.name: Wait List
fields.description: After being placed on the waiting list for lung transplant, individuals must be prepared to be called in for lung transplant at any time. Some people wait only hours or days and others wait years. The timing of “the call” depends on many factors including how sick the person waiting is, the availability of donor organs, and whether there are factors that make finding a match more challenging.
fields.content: After being placed on the waiting list for lung transplant, individuals must be prepared to be called in for lung transplant at any time. Some people wait only hours or days and others wait years. The timing of “the call” depends on many factors including how sick the person waiting is, the availability of donor organs, and whether there are factors that make finding a match more challenging.

fields.name: Carbon Dioxide
fields.description: Carbon dioxide is a toxin that can build up in a person’s blood when their lungs are not working normally.
fields.content: Carbon dioxide is a toxin that can build up in a person’s blood when their lungs are not working normally.

fields.name: BiPAP
fields.description: Bi-level positive airway pressure; this is a form of non-invasive ventilation that is used to help people remove carbon dioxide from their body. BiPAP is delivered by a mask on the face.
fields.content: Bi-level positive airway pressure; this is a form of non-invasive ventilation that is used to help people remove carbon dioxide from their body. BiPAP is delivered by a mask on the face.

fields.name: Travel Plan
fields.description: Transplant centers require lung transplant candidates to stay within a certain distance of the center at all times so they can arrive quickly if a donor becomes available. The distance varies from center to center. Most transplant centers require candidates to have a plan in place for how they will get to the transplant center once they receive the call for transplant.
fields.content: Transplant centers require lung transplant candidates to stay within a certain distance of the center at all times so they can arrive quickly if a donor becomes available. The distance varies from center to center. Most transplant centers require candidates to have a plan in place for how they will get to the transplant center once they receive the call for transplant.

fields.name: Pre-op Tests
fields.description: Pre-operative tests may be checked just prior to transplant to ensure a candidate remains healthy enough for the transplant surgery. The tests typically include blood work, imaging (e.g. chest x-ray), and testing for respiratory viruses (including COVID-19).
fields.content: Pre-operative tests may be checked just prior to transplant to ensure a candidate remains healthy enough for the transplant surgery. The tests typically include blood work, imaging (e.g. chest x-ray), and testing for respiratory viruses (including COVID-19).

fields.name: ICU
fields.description: Intensive Care Unit (ICU): Following a lung transplant, patients are closely monitored in the intensive care unit. Depending on how well the new lungs are working, people spend hours to days on the ventilator with a breathing tube (endotracheal tube) in place.
fields.content: Intensive Care Unit (ICU): Following a lung transplant, patients are closely monitored in the intensive care unit. Depending on how well the new lungs are working, people spend hours to days on the ventilator with a breathing tube (endotracheal tube) in place.

fields.name: Intubated
fields.description: Having a breathing tube (endotracheal tube) in a person’s windpipe (trachea) to allow connection to a mechanical ventilator for assistance with breathing. Some people are heavily sedated while others are able to be fully awake while on the ventilator, but this depends on multiple medical factors and how tolerant of the breathing tube the patient is.
fields.content: Having a breathing tube (endotracheal tube) in a person’s windpipe (trachea) to allow connection to a mechanical ventilator for assistance with breathing. Some people are heavily sedated while others are able to be fully awake while on the ventilator, but this depends on multiple medical factors and how tolerant of the breathing tube the patient is.

fields.name: Extubated
fields.description: Having the breathing tube (endotracheal tube) removed. Once extubated, a person breathes on their own without the assistance of the ventilator.
fields.content: Having the breathing tube (endotracheal tube) removed. Once extubated, a person breathes on their own without the assistance of the ventilator.

fields.name: Sepsis
fields.description: A severe, dangerous reaction that the body may have to an infection.
fields.content: A severe, dangerous reaction that the body may have to an infection.

fields.name: Sternum
fields.description: Commonly called the “breastbone.” It is the bone in the center of the front of the chest and connects the ribs to form the rib cage.
fields.content: Commonly called the “breastbone.” It is the bone in the center of the front of the chest and connects the ribs to form the rib cage.

fields.name: Restrictions
fields.description: In order to support healing of the broken sternum, or breastbone, lung transplant recipients are placed on sternal precautions or restrictions. These restrictions include limits on how the patient can move or twist and how heavy objects they carry can be.
fields.content: In order to support healing of the broken sternum, or breastbone, lung transplant recipients are placed on sternal precautions or restrictions. These restrictions include limits on how the patient can move or twist and how heavy objects they carry can be.

fields.name: Wires
fields.description: There are monitors for heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation that remain continuously connected initially. There are multiple types of intravenous (IV) lines/tubes.
fields.content: There are monitors for heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation that remain continuously connected initially. There are multiple types of intravenous (IV) lines/tubes.

fields.name: Discharged
fields.description: Allowed to leave the hospital.
fields.content: Allowed to leave the hospital.

fields.name: Oxygen Saturation
fields.description: The fraction of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin relative to the total hemoglobin in the blood. Oxygen saturation is normally 95-100%.
fields.content: The fraction of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin relative to the total hemoglobin in the blood. Oxygen saturation is normally 95-100%.

fields.name: Pulmonary Function Test
fields.description: The pulmonary function test most commonly used is spirometry. Spirometry measures how much air the lungs are moving (volume) and how quickly (flow). The FEV1 and FVC are two important measurements from spirometry that are tracked over time for people with a lung transplant.
fields.content: The pulmonary function test most commonly used is spirometry. Spirometry measures how much air the lungs are moving (volume) and how quickly (flow). The FEV1 and FVC are two important measurements from spirometry that are tracked over time for people with a lung transplant.

fields.name: FEV1
fields.description: Forced expiratory volume in one second; this is a lung function measurement that describes how much air is breathed out in one second when a person is blowing out as hard as they can. FEV1 is used post-transplant to monitor the function of the lung transplant.
fields.content: Forced expiratory volume in one second; this is a lung function measurement that describes how much air is breathed out in one second when a person is blowing out as hard as they can. FEV1 is used to monitor how well lungs are working, both with CF-related lung disease and after lung transplant.

fields.name: Relocation
fields.description: Relocation after lung transplant is sometimes required by the lung transplant center. There are frequent doctor’s appointments scheduled early after the transplant. It is important to remain close to the transplant center so that you can be evaluated quickly if a complication arises.
fields.content: Relocation after lung transplant is sometimes required by the lung transplant center. There are frequent doctor’s appointments scheduled early after the transplant. It is important to remain close to the transplant center so that you can be evaluated quickly if a complication arises.

fields.name: Returning Home
fields.description: If a person relocates after transplant to be closer to the transplant center, multiple factors will influence the timing for returning home. The number and severity of complications after transplant, the strength of your support system, the distance to your permanent home, and how well you are managing the new medication and monitoring regimen will all be factors in the timing.
fields.content: If a person relocates after transplant to be closer to the transplant center, multiple factors will influence the timing for returning home. The number and severity of complications after transplant, the strength of your support system, the distance to your permanent home, and how well you are managing the new medication and monitoring regimen will all be factors in the timing.

fields.name: Supplemental Oxygen
fields.description: Supplemental oxygen is a higher concentration of oxygen that is prescribed to treat low oxygen levels.
fields.content: Supplemental oxygen is a higher concentration of oxygen that is prescribed to treat low oxygen levels.

fields.name: Nebulizer
fields.description: Nebulizers are drug delivery devices used to administer medication in the form of a mist inhaled into the lungs. Nebulizers are commonly used for the treatment of cystic fibrosis. Typically, people living with CF use nebulizers for hours each day prior to lung transplant.
fields.content: Nebulizers are drug delivery devices used to administer medication in the form of a mist inhaled into the lungs. Nebulizers are commonly used for the treatment of cystic fibrosis. Typically, people living with CF use nebulizers for hours each day prior to lung transplant.

fields.name: Immune Suppression
fields.description: The dampening of the immune system’s strength. Immune suppression is necessary so that the body accepts the transplanted organ. Immune suppression requires multiple medications, some of which require blood tests for monitoring levels.
fields.content: The dampening of the immune system’s strength. Immune suppression is necessary so that the body accepts the transplanted organ. Immune suppression requires multiple medications, some of which require blood tests for monitoring levels.

fields.name: Diabetes
fields.description: People with CF frequently have diabetes at the time of lung transplant and many go on to develop diabetes after transplant. The risk of diabetes is related to problems in the pancreas due to CF, but diabetes can also be induced by medications (e.g. prednisone) after transplant.
fields.content: People with CF frequently have diabetes at the time of lung transplant and many go on to develop diabetes after transplant. The risk of diabetes is related to problems in the pancreas due to CF, but diabetes can also be induced by medications (e.g. prednisone) after transplant.

fields.name: Insulin
fields.description: Insulin is a medication used to treat diabetes. Insulin is injected under the skin in response to measured blood sugar (blood glucose) levels.
fields.content: Insulin is a medication used to treat diabetes. Insulin is injected under the skin in response to measured blood sugar (blood glucose) levels.

fields.name: Dexcom G6
fields.description: Dexcom G6 is a brand of continuous glucose monitor. The Dexcom G6 has an associated app that gives real-time feedback about blood sugar (blood glucose) levels.
fields.content: Dexcom G6 is a brand of continuous glucose monitor. The Dexcom G6 has an associated app that gives real-time feedback about blood sugar (blood glucose) levels.

fields.name: Support System
fields.description: A support system can include family, friends, online support groups, and others. People in your support system can provide mental/emotional support as you deal with uncertainty or complications before and after transplant. A support system is also useful for providing physical help – carrying/transporting medical equipment, delivering needed items to the hospital, providing meals.
fields.content: A support system can include family, friends, online support groups, and others. People in your support system can provide mental/emotional support as you deal with uncertainty or complications before and after transplant. A support system is also useful for providing physical help – carrying/transporting medical equipment, delivering needed items to the hospital, providing meals.

fields.name: Complications
fields.description: Complications are common but are largely treatable and manageable. Complications after transplant may include bleeding, developing a lung collapse (pneumothorax), heart rhythm abnormalities (arrhythmias), or infections. The need for re-intubation (replacement of the breathing tube) for mechanical ventilation can also occur.
fields.content: Complications are common but are largely treatable and manageable. Complications after transplant may include bleeding, developing a lung collapse (pneumothorax), heart rhythm abnormalities (arrhythmias), or infections. The need for re-intubation (replacement of the breathing tube) for mechanical ventilation can also occur.

fields.name: Respiratory Failure
fields.description: Occurs when lungs can’t get enough oxygen into the blood.
fields.content: Occurs when lungs can’t get enough oxygen into the blood.

fields.name: Ventilator
fields.description: A machine that helps someone breathe.
fields.content: A machine that helps someone breathe.

fields.name: Trach
fields.description: An incision in the neck is made in order to insert a tube that brings air to the lungs.
fields.content: An incision in the neck is made in order to insert a tube that brings air to the lungs.

fields.name: Low Oxygen
fields.description: Some people living with advanced CF lung disease have low oxygen levels in the blood. Supplemental oxygen may be prescribed to treat low levels. It is typically delivered through plastic tubing from an oxygen tank or concentrator.
fields.content: Some people living with advanced CF lung disease have low oxygen levels in the blood. Supplemental oxygen may be prescribed to treat low levels. It is typically delivered through plastic tubing from an oxygen tank or concentrator.

fields.name: Transplant Center
fields.description: Certain hospitals that offer lung transplants.
fields.content: Certain hospitals that offer lung transplants.

fields.name: Antibiotics
fields.description: Antibiotics are used to treat infections caused by bacteria. They are used to treat worsened symptoms of illness (increased cough, sputum production, shortness of breath) and decrease in lung function (e.g. FEV1).
fields.content: Antibiotics are used to treat infections caused by bacteria. They are used to treat worsened symptoms of illness (increased cough, sputum production, shortness of breath) and decrease in lung function (e.g. FEV1).

fields.name: Drug Resistant
fields.description: Resistance to antibiotics is a common issue for people with CF. Bacteria changes in ways that can cause antibiotics stop working.
fields.content: Resistance to antibiotics is a common issue for people with CF. Bacteria changes in ways that can cause antibiotics stop working.

fields.name: Long-term Respiratory Care Facility
fields.description: Care is provided on an ongoing basis in a living situation by respiratory and physical therapists and nurses.
fields.content: Care is provided on an ongoing basis in a living situation by respiratory and physical therapists and nurses.

fields.name: Scans
fields.description: Such as a bone density scan and chest CT scan
fields.content: Such as a bone density scan and chest CT scan

fields.name: Colonoscopy
fields.description: Cancer screening is a part of transplant evaluation. A colonoscopy is a common exam to detect changes or abnormalities in the large intestine and rectum. A long, flexible tube with a camera is inserted into the rectum so a doctor can view the inside of the entire colon.
fields.content: Cancer screening is a part of transplant evaluation. A colonoscopy is a common exam to detect changes or abnormalities in the large intestine and rectum. A long, flexible tube with a camera is inserted into the rectum so a doctor can view the inside of the entire colon.

fields.name: Trikafta
fields.description: Trikafta is a medication that treats the abnormal protein that causes CF. Modulators are only effective for people with certain CFTR mutations.  Trikafta was approved in October 2019 for use in the United States among people 12 years or older with at least one copy of the F508del mutation of CFTR and is a highly effective CFTR modulator.
fields.content: Trikafta is a medication that treats the abnormal protein that causes CF. Modulators are only effective for people with certain CFTR mutations.  Trikafta was approved in October 2019 for use in the United States among people 12 years or older with at least one copy of the F508del mutation of CFTR and is a highly effective CFTR modulator.

fields.name: Pulmonologist
fields.description: A physician who specializes in respiratory illnesses like CF.
fields.content: A physician who specializes in respiratory illnesses like CF.

fields.name: Physical Therapy
fields.description: Exercise and movement is important for people with advanced cystic fibrosis for posture, airway clearance, and body pain.
fields.content: Exercise and movement is important for people with advanced cystic fibrosis for posture, airway clearance, and body pain.

fields.name: Lung Function
fields.description: FEV1 (forced expiratory volume in one second) is a lung function measurement (a type of pulmonary function test or "PFT"). FEV1 measures the volume of air your lungs can breathe out in one second and is an accurate way to determine how well your lungs function. The FEV1 is an important component of the decision for a CF doctor to recommend lung transplant as a treatment option. FEV1 is also used after lung transplant to determine how well the lung transplant is working.
fields.content: FEV1 (forced expiratory volume in one second) is a lung function measurement (a type of pulmonary function test or "PFT"). FEV1 measures the volume of air your lungs can breathe out in one second and is an accurate way to determine how well your lungs function. The FEV1 is an important component of the decision for a CF doctor to recommend lung transplant as a treatment option. FEV1 is also used after lung transplant to determine how well the lung transplant is working.

fields.name: Call
fields.description: After being placed on the waiting list for lung transplant, individuals must be prepared to be called in for lung transplant at any time. Some people wait only hours or days and others wait years. The timing of “the call” depends on many factors including how sick the person waiting is, the availability of donor organs, and whether there are factors that make finding a match more challenging.
fields.content: After being placed on the waiting list for lung transplant, individuals must be prepared to be called in for lung transplant at any time. Some people wait only hours or days and others wait years. The timing of “the call” depends on many factors including how sick the person waiting is, the availability of donor organs, and whether there are factors that make finding a match more challenging.

fields.name: Dry Run
fields.description: “Dry run” is the circumstance when an individual is called to the hospital for lung transplant but the surgery is cancelled, often due to unforeseen problems with the donor lungs.
fields.content: “Dry run” is the circumstance when an individual is called to the hospital for lung transplant but the surgery is cancelled, often due to unforeseen problems with the donor lungs.

fields.name: Airlift
fields.description: Medical transport services by air.
fields.content: Medical transport services by air.

fields.name: Pulse Oximeter
fields.description: A pulse oximeter is a small device that clips onto the finger and measures the level of oxygen in the blood.
fields.content: A pulse oximeter is a small device that clips onto the finger and measures the level of oxygen in the blood.

fields.name: Health-related Quality of Life
fields.description: Lung transplant can improve quality of life within a few months after transplant for individuals with CF
fields.content: Lung transplant can improve quality of life within a few months after transplant for individuals with CF

fields.name: Pain Management
fields.description: Opioid medications are prescribed for pain management after lung transplant.
fields.content: Opioid medications are prescribed for pain management after lung transplant.

fields.name: Anti-Rejection Medication
fields.description: Medications are necessary so that the body accepts the transplanted organ. Some require blood tests for monitoring levels.
fields.content: Medications are necessary so that the body accepts the transplanted organ. Some require blood tests for monitoring levels.

fields.name: Tacrolimus
fields.description: Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressive drug used after lung transplant to lower the risk of organ rejection.
fields.content: Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressive drug used after lung transplant to lower the risk of organ rejection.

fields.name: Mycophenolate
fields.description: Mycophenolate is an immunosuppressive drug used after lung transplant to lower the risk of organ rejection.
fields.content: Mycophenolate is an immunosuppressive drug used after lung transplant to lower the risk of organ rejection.

fields.name: Prednisone
fields.description: A corticosteroid
fields.content: A corticosteroid

fields.name: 6MWT
fields.description: The six-minute walk test (6MWT) is used to measure walk distance, oxygen saturation and pulse rate during the test, and breathlessness after the test. It is a measure of physical conditioning or "functional status." As a person gets weaker, the walk distance decreases.
fields.content: The six-minute walk test (6MWT) is used to measure walk distance, oxygen saturation and pulse rate during the test, and breathlessness after the test. It is a measure of physical conditioning or "functional status." As a person gets weaker, the walk distance decreases.

fields.name: Chest Tubes
fields.description: Chest tubes are placed during the lung transplant surgery to help drain air, fluid, and blood from around the lungs and to help the new lungs remain inflated.
fields.content: Chest tubes are placed during the lung transplant surgery to help drain air, fluid, and blood from around the lungs and to help the new lungs remain inflated.

fields.name: Bronchoscopy
fields.description: A bronchoscopy is performed by a pulmonologist so they can look at the lungs and air passages. A thin tube (bronchoscope) is passed through the nose or mouth, down the throat and into the lungs.
fields.content: A bronchoscopy is performed by a pulmonologist so they can look at the lungs and air passages. A thin tube (bronchoscope) is passed through the nose or mouth, down the throat and into the lungs.

fields.name: Hypercapnia
fields.description: High levels of carbon dioxide in the blood. Carbon dioxide is a toxin that can build up in a person’s blood when their lungs are not working normally.
fields.content: High levels of carbon dioxide in the blood. Carbon dioxide is a toxin that can build up in a person’s blood when their lungs are not working normally.

fields.name: Gowning Up
fields.description: Infection control measure for CF patients.
fields.content: Infection control measure for CF patients.

fields.name: CTFR Genotype
fields.description: Cystic fibrosis is caused by mutations, or changes, in the CFTR gene. This gene provides the code that tells the body how to make the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein. CFTR mutations are grouped into classes based on the way the mutations affect the CFTR protein. The genotype describes which class of mutations exist, with F508del being the most common genotype.
fields.content: Cystic fibrosis is caused by mutations, or changes, in the CFTR gene. This gene provides the code that tells the body how to make the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein. CFTR mutations are grouped into classes based on the way the mutations affect the CFTR protein. The genotype describes which class of mutations exist, with F508del being the most common genotype.

fields.name: Numbness
fields.description: Numbness can occur around the chest incision.
fields.content: Numbness can occur around the chest incision.

fields.name: Taste
fields.description: Altered sense of taste and smell can be side effects of medications.
fields.content: Altered sense of taste and smell can be side effects of medications.

fields.name: Hand Tremors
fields.description: Hand tremors are a relatively common post-transplant symptom.
fields.content: Hand tremors are a relatively common post-transplant symptom.

fields.name: Adherence
fields.description: The degree to which a person follows medical advice – for example, taking medication, following a diet, and/or executing lifestyle changes.
fields.content: The degree to which a person follows medical advice – for example, taking medication, following a diet, and/or executing lifestyle changes.

fields.name: Nutrition
fields.description: There are studies showing that people with obesity or malnutrition before transplant are at a higher risk for having a difficult recovery and worse survival after transplant. For this reason, many lung transplant programs set absolute cutoffs for BMI so that those who are moderately-to-severely underweight or being obese can be ineligible for lung transplant. These thresholds are different at different programs across the country.
fields.content: There are studies showing that people with obesity or malnutrition before transplant are at a higher risk for having a difficult recovery and worse survival after transplant. For this reason, many lung transplant programs set absolute cutoffs for BMI so that those who are moderately-to-severely underweight or being obese can be ineligible for lung transplant. These thresholds are different at different programs across the country.

fields.name: Symdeko
fields.description: Symdeko, or tezacaftor/ivacaftor, is a CFTR modulator therapy for people with two copies of the F508del mutation. It is a component of Trikafta (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor). Symdeko (tezacaftor/ivacaftor) is not as effective at improving lung function as Trikafta (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor).
fields.content: Symdeko, or tezacaftor/ivacaftor, is a CFTR modulator therapy for people with two copies of the F508del mutation. It is a component of Trikafta (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor). Symdeko (tezacaftor/ivacaftor) is not as effective at improving lung function as Trikafta (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor).

fields.name: Orkambi
fields.description: Orkambi, or lumacaftor/ivacaftor, was the first CFTR modulator therapy approved for people with two copies of the F508del mutation. It was much less effective at improving lung function as Trikafta (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor) and caused more side effects.
fields.content: Orkambi, or lumacaftor/ivacaftor, was the first CFTR modulator therapy approved for people with two copies of the F508del mutation. It was much less effective at improving lung function as Trikafta (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor) and caused more side effects.

fields.name: Lung allocation score
fields.description: A number value used by the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) in the United States to assign relative priority for distributing donated lungs for transplantation.
fields.content: A number value used by the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) in the United States to assign relative priority for distributing donated lungs for transplantation.

fields.name: Rejection
fields.description: Your immune system is responsible for protecting you from infection. Immune cells recognize the transplanted lung as different from the rest of the body and attempt to destroy it, similar to an infection. This is called rejection, and it is your body's way of not accepting the new organ. After transplant surgery, you are prescribed immunosuppressive drugs to "fool" your immune system into thinking your new lung is your own so it doesn't try to attack it.
fields.content: Your immune system is responsible for protecting you from infection. Immune cells recognize the transplanted lung as different from the rest of the body and attempt to destroy it, similar to an infection. This is called rejection, and it is your body's way of not accepting the new organ. After transplant surgery, you are prescribed immunosuppressive drugs to "fool" your immune system into thinking your new lung is your own so it doesn't try to attack it.

fields.title: Planning for Transplant
fields.description: Planning for transplant can start years before lung transplant referral is considered. While lung transplant is not the right treatment option for all individuals with CF, the discussion is important for everyone.
fields.content: Planning for transplant can start years before lung transplant referral is considered. While lung transplant is not the right treatment option for all individuals with CF, the discussion is important for everyone. Annual discussion of lung transplant is recommended in CF Clinic for individuals with CF once their lung function reaches an FEV1 less than 50% of predicted. Planning for transplant involves understanding the stage of your CF (e.g. how sick your lungs are), the transplant referral process, possible barriers to transplant, and how to strengthen your health prior to transplant. It is important to consider the cost of lung transplant and your particular insurance requirements. A good support system contributes to having a successful transplant. Awareness about post-transplant outcomes is also part of planning for transplant and can help with expectations and processing your experiences after lung transplant. Connecting with individuals with CF who have had a lung transplant can be very helpful. Working together with your CF care team is important throughout the transplant journey. Ask your CF doctor when you have questions about lung transplant.

fields.title: Caregiver Information
fields.description: Being a caregiver is a commitment. Lung transplant caregiver requirements vary by lung transplant program, but generally must be adults who are nonsmokers, able to drive, and able to stay at the hospital while the patient is recovering from the transplant surgery.
fields.content:
Being a caregiver is a commitment. Lung transplant caregiver requirements vary by lung transplant program, but generally must be adults who are nonsmokers, able to drive, and able to stay at the hospital while the patient is recovering from the transplant surgery. Caregivers advocate for their loved ones in the hospital and post-transplant.

The recovery period can mean constant care-taking. One caregiver said, “I knew I would pretty much have to run the show, take care of her around the clock.” Responsibilities include helping with bathing, medications, shopping, cooking and cleaning, monitoring conditions such as diabetes, and accompanying the patient to appointments. A patient may need additional support and help for family members such as their spouse or children.

Caregivers talk about the benefits of seeing and talking to their own friends. They benefit from help from neighbors and extended family so that they can take breaks. One caregiver said, “Expect frustration, a little anxiety, and just being burnt out.” Self-care is very important for the caregiver.

Often, when a patient becomes aware that there are sacrifices and responsibilities, they become concerned about the experience of their caregivers. One pre-transplant candidate said, “I feel like there’s a lot of emotional support for me – yeah, what I’m going to go through is really hard, but they’re going to be the ones that are trying to figure out how to care for me best.”

Additional tips from caregivers include: use of a Caring Bridge journal to keep people informed and a few key contacts to pass along news. Accept the offer of a meal train for regular nutritious food. Enlist help for gardening, pets, and cleaning. Be realistic about how much time you’ll spend caregiving.

fields.title: Cost
fields.content:
Many factors contribute to the financial cost of lung transplant. There are costs while being evaluated, while waiting for transplant, during the transplant hospitalization, for housing near the transplant center before and/or after transplant, and long-term after transplant. It is also important to consider the potential for disability/lost wages before or while recovering from transplant, which can also affect caregivers who may need to help with your care for a period. Some costs may be covered by health insurance, while others require out-of-pocket payments. The choice of health insurance is always important for individuals with chronic health conditions like CF, but even more important when a person with CF is nearing lung transplant. The CF Foundation’s Compass program is a one-on-one service available to help individuals with CF and their family members navigate insurance, financial, or legal issues. Your CF Center’s social worker and/or lung transplant program’s social worker can provide guidance about saving money for transplant-related expenses and fundraising. Requirements for the amount of savings or financial resources varies from transplant center to transplant center. One CF lung transplant recipient put it best, “I've seen a number of patients who were not listed because they, for lack of a better way of putting it, failed the financial test. That's a terrible reason to be denied being listed. But I guess if there’s a way – if you’re going to be talking to people ten years before transplant might be a necessity for them – and if you could somehow suggest that they start a piggy bank or something, that would not be a terrible idea. That's only one tiny aspect of preparing oneself for transplant, but like I said it’s pretty awful if that’s the only thing that keeps you from being listed.”

Read More (cost):

Testing during the evaluation, appointments with doctors/nutritionist/social worker, and procedures to address problems discovered during the evaluation may all come with co-pays or out-of-pocket costs. Depending on your insurance coverage, some tests may need to be performed at preferred or “in network” sites rather than at the lung transplant center. Understanding the requirements for your insurance policy will be necessary so you can  avoid surprise costs during the evaluation.

Insurance policies may also dictate which lung transplant programs are available to you for your transplant. If you are turned down for transplant at the insurance company’s preferred transplant program, it is typically possible to appeal for coverage at an alternative transplant center. This is especially relevant for CF patients with difficult to treat infections (e.g. Burkholderia cenocepacia) or conditions that make their transplant more challenging (e.g. the need for a combined organ transplant like lung-liver transplant).

If you need to relocate before (while waiting) and/or after lung transplant, there are sometimes insurance benefits to cover housing. Different transplant centers have differing requirements for how close to the hospital you need to remain while listed and after transplant.

Read more: CF Foundation: Compass

Children’s Organ Transplant Association (COTA), serving adults as well as children, is an organization that has a history of helping CF patients fundraise for lung transplant. They have a transplant cost estimator on their website: Cota

fields.title: Advanced Care Planning
fields.content:
People with serious illness benefit by planning for a future where they are likely to get sicker so that they can communicate their preferences to their providers and caregivers. Advance care planning is a process that includes conversations about treatment preferences as well as wishes for end-of-life care. As part of the lung transplant evaluation process, people with CF are expected to complete an advanced directive. A living will or healthcare advanced directive is a document that guides doctors and caregivers about the kinds of treatment decisions a person would prefer if he/she is seriously ill and unable to speak for him or herself. A durable power of attorney for healthcare is a document that allows a person to choose who they would want to act on his or her behalf for healthcare decisions if he or she was unable to speak for him/herself. This might be a spouse, significant other, family member, or friend. One purpose of advance care planning is to document a patient’s preferences in their electronic medical record so that medical providers can view and access this information if necessary.
Read more (advanced care planning):

Some people may also create an estate plan, which is a legally binding document that designates who would receive your assets if you were to die or become unable to care for yourself including finances. This can involve changing beneficiaries of life insurance policies and retirement accounts, selecting guardians for minor children, providing lifetime income for oneself or others, and minimizing taxes and other estate settlement costs.

Many people who do advance care planning find the involvement of their family and caregivers to be helpful.

fields.title: Support and Family Considerations
fields.content:
People who have been through the process of preparing for transplant find support from family, friends, and loved ones to be very helpful. Often, family members are part of the decision-making process. A lung transplant recipient said: “We had several conversations, because we knew [transplant] was coming.”

A family member can attend appointments to listen, ask questions, and learn more about ways to participate.

To be approved for lung transplant, a potential recipient usually needs to name caregivers to be involved. These caregivers need to be available while the person is on the waiting list and through their recovery from the transplant. Specific caregiver requirements can vary between transplant programs.

Family members and loved ones need information and access to resources specific to caregivers. They can experience their own stress and worry. Most transplant centers have support groups that family members can attend. Many people also find connection with others in similar situations by joining online groups.

People living through the transplant process may be so sick that they need constant care. One transplant recipient recommended "getting comfortable asking for help"

Informal caregivers pre-transplant may come from a large network of people who help with meals, babysitting, driving, fundraising, and more.

fields.title: Transplant Referral
fields.description: When you are referred, the transplant team will try to figure out how much transplant could help benefit you (the possible “benefits”), as well as how risky transplant may be for you.
fields.content:
Referral for lung transplant is a process that involves a consultation with a lung transplant center, explaining the reason for referral, and providing medical records. Transplant referral is an opportunity for your CF care team to discuss  details about your condition with experts in lung transplant.

The lung transplant center will assess whether you are eligibile for transplant after they receive the referral. Sometimes the assessment will involve an in-person (or telemedicine) clinic visit with members of the transplant team. The referral gives you and your family the chance to learn more about transplant, discuss potential “barriers,” or “contraindications”) to transplant, and/or complete a transplant evaluation (see Eligibility, Evaluation, and Listing below).

Timing of transplant referral can be classified as “early”, “timely”, or late”. Early referral occurs before transplant is needed. Early referral gives you more opportunity to ask questions and gather information, as well as to address any possible “barriers” to transplant, some of which may take years to correct (see Eligibility, Evaluation, and Listing below). The CF Foundation recommends early referral in order to give people living with CF the best chance to fully consider lung transplant and understand it as a treatment option. For people who are referred early, the lung transplant center may decide to wait longer before starting an evaluation

  • Timely referral occurs at the time that you actually have a medical need or “indication” for lung transplant (see Signs that CF is Worsening below).
  • Late referral occurs when you are too sick to undergo a routine transplant evaluation and is considered an emergency. Late referral can happen in the setting of an unexpectedly severe exacerbation from which you do not recover, especially if you require mechanical ventilation or other intensive care. Late referral can lead to dying without transplant because there is too little time to be listed, or if a donor organ doesn’t become available in time.  Some lung transplant programs do not offer emergency evaluations.

fields.title: Timing of Referral
fields.content:
Referral for lung transplant is a process that involves sending a request for consultation to a lung transplant center, transmitting medical records, and explaining the reason for referral.

Transplant referral provides an opportunity for your CF care team to discuss the details of your condition with the experts in lung transplant.

The lung transplant center will assess your eligibility for transplant after they receive the referral. Sometimes the assessment will involve an in-person (or telemedicine) clinic visit with members of the transplant team. The referral gives you and your family the chance to learn more about transplant, discuss potential “barriers” (“contraindications”) to transplant, and/or complete an evaluation (see Eligibility, Evaluation, and Listing below).

Early referral occurs prior to the medical need for transplant and gives you the opportunity to ask questions and gather information without the pressure of an immediate medical indication for lung transplant. The CF Foundation recommends early referral in order to give people living with CF the best chance to fully consider lung transplant and understand it as a treatment option. Further, early referral gives you time to address any possible “barriers” to transplant. Some barriers to transplant may take years to correct (see Eligibility, Evaluation, and Listing below). For people who are referred early, the lung transplant center may decide to wait longer before starting a full evaluation (e.g. testing, procedures, appointments with specialists).

Timely referral occurs when you have a medical need or “indication” for lung transplant (see Signs that CF is Worsening below). Your CF team and lung transplant team will agree that it is time to move forward with a full evaluation (see Eligibility, Evaluation, and Listing below).

Late referral occurs when you are too sick to undergo a routine transplant evaluation and this is seen as an emergency. Late referral can happen in the setting of an unexpectedly severe exacerbation from which you do not recover, especially if you require mechanical ventilation or other intensive care. Late referral can lead to dying without transplant because there is too little time to proceed with listing or limited lung donor availability (e.g. cannot find a match in time). Some lung transplant programs do not offer emergency evaluations.

fields.title: Factors in the Decision to Refer
fields.description: There are a number of factors that can influence when your cystic fibrosis care team refers you to lung transplant. The biggest factor in the decision to refer for lung transplant is your lung function, as measured by FEV1 % of predicted.
fields.content:
The biggest factor in the decision to refer for lung transplant is your lung function, as measured by FEV1 % of predicted. When your FEV1 decreases, it is a sign that your CF is worsening.

There are different lung function thresholds for referral of adults (age 18 years and older) versus children or adolescents. The CF Foundation recommends referring children who have low FEV1 sooner (at a higher level of FEV1 % of predicted)

How quickly your lung function is decreasing is also a factor in the decision to refer. If you experience a 20% decrease in your FEV1 % of predicted over the course of 1 year, that is a sign that your CF is worsening.

Everyone with an FEV1 less than 30% of predicted should be referred for lung transplant.

Adults with FEV1 between 30% and 40% of predicted should be checked for other signs of worsening CF. For people with lung function in this range, there are certain factors that can prompt referral to a transplant center for consideration of lung transplant (see Signs that CF is Worsening below).

The use of CFTR modulators (e.g. elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor) can lead to large improvements in lung function, nutritional status, and other aspects of CF. How long CFTR modulators can delay lung transplant for people with CF is still unknown.

Distance from the transplant center may be a factor in the timing of referral because it may be more difficult and time consuming to complete an evaluation in that setting. It is important to understand whether you will need to move to a new city for lung transplant, since that may take months or years of planning.

Younger women should be referred early. There is a “gender gap” in survival for people living with CF - women are at an increased risk of dying without lung transplant compared to men. There is no difference in post-lung transplant survival between women and men with CF. Women who have CF-related diabetes, rapidly decreasing BMI, or rapidly decreasing FEV1 are considered the highest risk.

For individuals who are shorter (height under 162 cm or 5 feet 4 inches), there is an increased risk of dying without transplant. The risk is partly explained because it is more difficult to find lung donors with lungs that are the correct size (see Transplant Operation below). Waiting times are longer for people who are shorter.

Certain types of infections can limit which transplant centers will consider you for a lung transplant (see Contraindications/Modifiable Barriers below). Early referral allows time to determine whether your local transplant center considers a specific infection an absolute barrier to transplant and if you will need to approach other transplant centers (which can be time consuming and expensive if you need to travel).

If you have liver or kidney disease and may need multiple organs transplanted, early referral is recommended because not all transplant centers perform multi-organ transplants (more than just the lungs at one time) and waiting times can be longer when multiple organs are needed for one recipient.

It is important to recognize that referral does not necessarily prompt a full evaluation or listing, but instead gives individuals with CF, their families, and providers access to the expertise of the transplant team and the opportunity to fully consider lung transplant as a treatment option.

fields.title: Signs that CF is Worsening
fields.description: For adults with FEV1 between 30% and 40% of predicted, CF care teams should evaluate for the presence of other signs that your CF is worsening. The signs may include frequent or severe exacerbations, a low BMI, or low oxygen saturation, among others.
fields.content:
Low lung function, as measured by FEV1 % of predicted, is the strongest sign of worsening CF.

For adults with FEV1 between 30% and 40% of predicted, or children with FEV1 between 40% and 50% of predicted, CF care teams should evaluate for the presence of other signs that your CF is worsening (see Table below)

Once your FEV1 is less than 40% of predicted (or less than 50% of predicted for children), testing should occur at least once per year to evaluate your 6-minute walk test distance, oxygen saturation with exercise and during sleep, and level of carbon dioxide in the blood. You should also have an echocardiogram (an ultrasound of the heart) at least once to check for signs of pulmonary hypertension (high blood pressures seen on the right side of the heart).

Referral for lung transplant is recommended if you have low lung function and any additional signs that your CF is worsening.

Frequent or severe exacerbations: IV antibiotics more than 2 times in 1 year or 1 exacerbation that required ICU admission and the use of BiPAP or a ventilator

Low BMI: less than 18 kg/m for adults or less than 5th percentile for children

6-minute walk test less than 400 meters (1,312 feet)

Low oxygen saturation (less than 88%) at rest, with exercise, or while sleeping

High carbon dioxide levels in the blood (“hypercapnia”)

Pulmonary hypertension: high blood pressure on the right side of the heart

Massive hemoptysis (coughing up a large amount of blood): more than 240 mL (1 cup) over a short time, requiring intensive care and/or bronchial artery embolization to stop the bleeding

Pneumothorax (“lung collapse”)

fields.title: CF-Specific Psychosocial Concerns
fields.content:
Adherence

Family (young children)

Mental health issues - depression, anxiety

Employment/finances

Feeling like a burden

fields.title: Eligibility, Evaluation, and Listing
fields.description: The transplant team will outline a list of specific steps that you will need to finish before you can be placed on the waiting list. The steps will be a combination of tests, procedures, and visits with medical providers.
fields.content: To figure out how much transplant could help you (the benefits), the transplant team will review how sick you are right now: How you feel, whether you are getting worse, how often you are in the hospital or needing antibiotics, your lung function, and other problems or test results to understand your quality of life and chance of dying from your CF lung disease.

fields.title: Contraindications/Modifiable Barriers to Transplant
fields.content:
When you are referred, the transplant team will try to figure out how much transplant could help you (the possible “benefits”), as well as how risky transplant may be for you. This is called “weighing the benefits and risks”, and will start with the team reading information in your medical chart, discussions with your CF team, and/or an in-person visit.

To figure out how much transplant could help you (the benefits), the transplant team will review how sick you are right now: How you feel, whether you are getting worse, how often you are in the hospital or needing antibiotics, your lung function, and other problems or test results to understand your quality of life and chance of dying from your CF lung disease. The transplant team will usually wait to put you onto the waiting list until they feel that your chance of dying is high within the next two years.

The transplant team will also want to make sure that transplant isn’t too risky. There are risks for any person, but some people may have conditions or problems that reduce the chance of transplant going well (make it riskier). These can be thought of as “barriers” or “contraindications” to transplant, and may prevent a person from being eligible. Common barriers to transplant in people with CF are in the table below:

Not having caregiver(s) to help you before or after transplant

Uncontrolled anxiety, depression, or other mental health problems

Not having insurance or money to pay for post-transplant care

Uncontrolled diabetes

Substance abuse

Poor nutrition

Poor physical health (“deconditioning”)

Some infections (Burkholderia cenocepacia, Mycobacterium abscessus)

Not taking your medicines as directed before transplant

Liver disease

Severe pain requiring opioid pain medications

Being too sick for transplant

Many of these barriers can improve over time with teamwork between you, your caregivers, your CF team, and the transplant team. Improvements can help with your chance of success with transplant and at the same time help you feel better before transplant. It is important to discuss strategies with your CF team as soon as possible. Sometimes, a transplant program will set goals or specific requirements that you will need to meet before you will be placed on the waiting list.

It may be impossible to change some of these barriers (contraindications), and how this is handled can vary based on the specific situation and transplant program. For example, having Mycobacterium abscessus in the sputum may prevent a person with CF from being eligible for transplant at some, but not all, transplant centers. Contraindications are best discussed between you, your CF team, and the transplant team as early as possible. Sometimes, your CF team can also contact a different transplant center with more experience handling the specific issue(s).

fields.title: Evaluation Process
fields.description: The transplant team will outline a list of specific steps that you will need to finish before you can be placed on the waiting list.
fields.content:
The transplant team will outline a list of specific steps that you will need to finish before you can be placed on the waiting list. The steps will be a combination of tests, procedures, and visits with medical providers. The goals of this “evaluation” are to:

  1. Better determine how much you can benefit from transplant
  2. Identify conditions that could be optimized to improve your chance of success with transplant.
  3. Identify conditions that could make transplant too risky (contraindications)

Specific steps vary based on your age, medical history, how sick you are, the transplant program, and other factors. Some you may have already completed as part of routine CF care and the transplant team will need to gather records. Some can be done in your home town, but others may need to be done at the transplant center.

Common steps in the evaluation process for people with CF are listed below:

Diagnostic Tests

  • Blood tests
  • Pulmonary function tests
  • 6-minute walk test
  • Echocardiogram
  • Heart catheterization
  • Acid reflux testing

Imaging

  • Chest X-ray
  • Chest CT scan
  • Abdominal imaging (ultrasound or CT)
  • Sinus imaging
  • Bone density scan

Health Maintenance

  • Dental examination
  • Routine vaccinations
  • Updated cancer screening based on age and gender (colonoscopy, PAP smear, mammogram, prostate cancer testing, other)

Specialist Visits

  • Visit(s) with transplant pulmonologist
  • Visit(s) with transplant social worker
  • Visit(s) with a transplant financial counselor
  • Visit(s) with transplant mental health provider
  • Visit(s) with transplant dietitian
  • Visit(s) with transplant surgeon
  • Visit(s) with a pharmacist
  • Visit(s) with an otolaryngologist (ear, nose, and throat doctor) for sinus care
  • Visit(s) with an endocrinologist if you have diabetes or low bone density (osteopenia/osteoporosis)
  • Visit(s) with a hepatologist (liver doctor if there are signs of liver disease
  • Visit(s) with an allergist if you have medication allergies

fields.title: Waiting on the list
fields.description: After you have finished your evaluation the transplant team will decide about putting you on the waiting list (“listing” you) for donor lungs. After you have been listed, waiting times for transplant vary based on how sick you are, your transplant program, your height/size, your blood type. Across the U.S., in 2018 half of listed people waited less than 2.5 months for lungs, and half waited longer than 2.5 months.
fields.content:
After you have finished your evaluation the transplant team will decide about putting you on the waiting list (“listing” you). They will let you know whether you are listed, or whether you need to finish any additional steps to help decide whether transplant is the right decision for you at this time. Sometimes, especially if your CF lung disease has been stable, they may want to see you back in clinic at least once before listing you. 

After you’ve been listed, waiting times for transplant vary based on how sick you are, your transplant program, your height/size, your blood type, and whether you have antibodies in the blood that could make you ineligible for some donor lungs. Across the U.S., in 2018 half of listed people waited less than 2.5 months for lungs, and half waited longer than 2.5 months, but this number varies a lot based on the transplant program and the other factors above. How sick you are is measured by the “lung allocation score (LAS)”, which is calculated based on your test results including lung function, oxygen requirement, blood tests, etc. The U.S. system’s goal is to transplant the sickest patients (with the highest LAS) first. Across the U.S., about 10-20% of people on the waiting list die before receiving a transplant or become too sick and are removed from the list. As people get sicker from their lung disease, their LAS should increase to help improve their chance of getting lungs more quickly.

While listed, you will follow up with your transplant center at least every 3 months. If you are very sick they may ask you to come more frequently. They will update tests and your LAS regularly. It is important to continue regular follow ups and communicate closely with your CF and transplant teams, especially if you feel like you are getting sicker or for other changes in your health. It is also important while listed to continue working on any modifiable barriers to transplant that you may have (see table above) including nutrition, physical conditioning, diabetes, etc. This will help improve your health while listed, help improve your chance of success with transplant, and make sure you remain a good candidate for transplant.

fields.title: Transplant Operation
fields.content:
Dry runs

Surgery

(photos)

Chest tubes are initially connected to suction, but as the lungs heal and remain inflated on their own the chest tube does less of the work. Chest tubes are placed to “water seal” – meaning no suction – to continue draining fluid. Once the fluid drainage slows down and the lungs remain inflated, the chest tubes will be “clamped” (like bending a hose to prevent the flow of water) and then removed. For many people the removal of chest tubes is the determining factor for when they can be safely sent home from the hospital.

Recovery

fields.title: Surviving and thriving after transplant
fields.content:
CF-specific survival statistics and HRQOL

Medications and Adherence

The pulmonary function test most commonly used is spirometry. Spirometry measures how much air the lungs are moving (volume) and how quickly (flow). The FEV1 and FVC are two important measurements from spirometry that are tracked over time for people with a lung transplant. 

Immunosuppression

Immune suppression increases the risk of infection and cancer.

fields.title: Mental health
fields.content:
Psychological Considerations

Mental health counselors can aid people with CF in finding ways to balance their illness with activities that make life satisfying and meaningful.  They are trained in coping techniques and problem-solving strategies for maintaining good physical and mental health. Trained psychologists can offer evidence-based interventions, such as cognitive behavioral therapy, intended to decrease anxiety and improve resilience.

Social workers also have an important role to play in the transplant process. They can help patients and their families cope more effectively with the stress of the transplant evaluation by offering support, practical help, and advice. Living with CF can involve considerable expenses, and insurance benefits can be extremely complex. Social workers have a working knowledge of existing resources. Social work services in CF clinic include:

  • Acting as an advocate and liaison
  • Financial, benefit, and housing advice
  • Referrals to other supporting services or clinicians for parents and caregivers
  • Emotional support
  • Counseling
